R6.nl_constraint: A person should never be debarked in a same city more than once

children.nl_constraint: For each person and each city combination, the total number of times that person has gotten off an aircraft in that city should never exceed one.

content.text:
<documents>
<pddl_domain>
;; Enrico Scala (enricos83@gmail.com) and Miquel Ramirez (miquel.ramirez@gmail.com)
(define (domain zenotravel)
        ;(:requirements :typing :fluents)
        (:types
                locatable city - object
                aircraft person - locatable
        )
        (:predicates
                (located ?x - locatable ?c - city)
                (in ?p - person ?a - aircraft)
        )
        (:functions
                (fuel ?a - aircraft)
                (distance ?c1 - city ?c2 - city)
                (slow_burn ?a - aircraft)
                (fast_burn ?a - aircraft)
                (capacity ?a - aircraft)
                (total_fuel_used)
                (onboard ?a - aircraft)
                (zoom_limit ?a - aircraft)

                (n_board ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_debark ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_flyslow ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_flyfast ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_refuel ?a - aircraft)
        )

        (:action board
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?p ?c)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (located ?p ?c))
                        (in ?p ?a)
                        (increase (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_board ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action debark
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (in ?p ?a)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (in ?p ?a))
                        (located ?p ?c)
                        (decrease (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_debark ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action flyslow
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow_burn ?a))))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total_fuel_used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow_burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow_burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyslow ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action flyfast
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast_burn ?a)))
                        (<= (onboard ?a) (zoom_limit ?a)))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total_fuel_used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast_burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast_burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyfast ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action refuel
                :parameters (?a - aircraft)
                :precondition (and (> (capacity ?a) (fuel ?a))

                )
                :effect (and (assign (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))
                        (increase (n_refuel ?a) 1))
        )

)
</pddl_domain>
<pddl_problem>
(define (problem ZTRAVEL-3-10)
(:domain zenotravel)
(:objects
	plane1 - aircraft
	plane2 - aircraft
	plane3 - aircraft
	person1 - person
	person2 - person
	person3 - person
	person4 - person
	person5 - person
	person6 - person
	person7 - person
	person8 - person
	person9 - person
	person10 - person
	city0 - city
	city1 - city
	city2 - city
	city3 - city
	city4 - city
	city5 - city
	)
(:init
	(located plane1 city4)
	(= (capacity plane1) 2326)
	(= (fuel plane1) 205)
	(= (slow_burn plane1) 1)
	(= (fast_burn plane1) 2)
	(= (onboard plane1) 0)
	(= (zoom_limit plane1) 10)
	(located plane2 city2)
	(= (capacity plane2) 12132)
	(= (fuel plane2) 1469)
	(= (slow_burn plane2) 4)
	(= (fast_burn plane2) 9)
	(= (onboard plane2) 0)
	(= (zoom_limit plane2) 9)
	(located plane3 city3)
	(= (capacity plane3) 5204)
	(= (fuel plane3) 1532)
	(= (slow_burn plane3) 2)
	(= (fast_burn plane3) 7)
	(= (onboard plane3) 0)
	(= (zoom_limit plane3) 8)
	(located person1 city1)
	(located person2 city2)
	(located person3 city1)
	(located person4 city4)
	(located person5 city5)
	(located person6 city1)
	(located person7 city0)
	(located person8 city2)
	(located person9 city1)
	(located person10 city5)
	(= (distance city0 city0) 0)
	(= (distance city0 city1) 619)
	(= (distance city0 city2) 565)
	(= (distance city0 city3) 886)
	(= (distance city0 city4) 596)
	(= (distance city0 city5) 766)
	(= (distance city1 city0) 619)
	(= (distance city1 city1) 0)
	(= (distance city1 city2) 561)
	(= (distance city1 city3) 756)
	(= (distance city1 city4) 760)
	(= (distance city1 city5) 980)
	(= (distance city2 city0) 565)
	(= (distance city2 city1) 561)
	(= (distance city2 city2) 0)
	(= (distance city2 city3) 657)
	(= (distance city2 city4) 702)
	(= (distance city2 city5) 639)
	(= (distance city3 city0) 886)
	(= (distance city3 city1) 756)
	(= (distance city3 city2) 657)
	(= (distance city3 city3) 0)
	(= (distance city3 city4) 546)
	(= (distance city3 city5) 510)
	(= (distance city4 city0) 596)
	(= (distance city4 city1) 760)
	(= (distance city4 city2) 702)
	(= (distance city4 city3) 546)
	(= (distance city4 city4) 0)
	(= (distance city4 city5) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city0) 766)
	(= (distance city5 city1) 980)
	(= (distance city5 city2) 639)
	(= (distance city5 city3) 510)
	(= (distance city5 city4) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city5) 0)
	(= (total_fuel_used) 0)
)
(:goal (and
	(located plane1 city4)
	(located person1 city4)
	(located person2 city5)
	(located person3 city4)
	(located person4 city0)
	(located person5 city2)
	(located person6 city3)
	(located person8 city0)
	(located person9 city3)
	(located person10 city4)
	))

(:metric minimize (total_fuel_used))





)
</pddl_problem>
</documents> 

<information>
The user will give as input a natural language constraint that must be translated into PDDL3.0. The translation will be used by a PDDL planner.
</information>

<instructions> 
- Translate the input constraint into correct PDDL3.0.
- The resulting PDDL3.0 constraint must capture the same meaning as the initial input constraint.
- Remember that PDDL3.0 constraints are state-based. They can only refer to existing precates and fluents, thus, not to actions.
- Be sure to include temporal logic like operators in your translation.
- Format your answer such as there is no preambule and such that the PDDL translation is between the tags <pddl> and </pddl>.
</instructions>

<user_input>
For each person and each city combination, the total number of times that person has gotten off an aircraft in that city should never exceed one.
</user_input>

Let me understand this constraint:

"For each person and each city combination, the total number of times that person has gotten off an aircraft in that city should never exceed one."

This means that for any person P and any city C, the person P should never debark (get off) an aircraft more than once in city C.

Looking at the domain, I can see there's a function:
(n_debark ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)

This function counts the number of times person ?p has debarked from aircraft ?a in city ?c.

However, the constraint is about the total number of times a person has gotten off an aircraft in a city, regardless of which aircraft. So I need to sum over all aircraft.

In PDDL3.0, I need to express this as an always constraint that applies throughout the execution.

The constraint should be:
For all person P and city C: (sum over all aircraft A of (n_debark P A C)) <= 1

In PDDL3.0 syntax, this would be:
(always (forall (?p - person ?c - city) 
    (<= (+ (n_debark ?p plane1 ?c) (n_debark ?p plane2 ?c) (n_debark ?p plane3 ?c)) 1)))

Wait, let me think about this more carefully. The constraint should be that the sum over all aircraft of the number of times person P debarked from any aircraft in city C should never exceed 1.

Since we have specific aircraft (plane1, plane2, plane3), I need to sum over all of them:

(always (forall (?p - person ?c - city) 
    (<= (+ (n_debark ?p plane1 ?c) (n_debark ?p plane2 ?c) (n_debark ?p plane3 ?c)) 1)))

This captures the meaning: for each person-city combination, the total number of debarkations (across all aircraft) should never exceed 1.

<information>
The user will give as input a constraint in natural language. This constraint must be used as a transjectory hard constraint for the solution plan of the given the PDDL problem. 
</information>

<instructions> 
- Refine the user constraint to make it applicable to the given PDDL problem.
- You can rephrase and decompose the initial constraint into several other contraints.
- These constraints should be complementary and they will be later combined with AND operators.
- Constraints must be state-based and follow a Linear Temporal Logic. So constraints can't directly refer to actions.
- Avoid explicit PDDL language in your answer, the user can't understand PDDL.
- The set of all refined constraints must capture the meaning of the initial user constraint. 
- Format your answer as a clear and concise numbered list between the tags <constraints> and </constraints>. There should be no subitems, only the list of refined constraints.
- After, add 1 or 2 sentences to explain your choice of decomposition between the tags <explanation> and </explanation>.
- Here is an example of how to format your answer:
    <constraints>
        1. [natural_language_constraint_1]
        2. [natural_language_constraint_2]
        ...
    </constraints>
    <explanation>
        [consice_explanation]
    </explanation>
</instructions>

<user_input>
A person should never be debarked in a same city more than once
</user_input>

Let me analyze this constraint in the context of the given PDDL problem.

The user constraint is: "A person should never be debarked in a same city more than once"

Looking at the PDDL domain, I can see there's a `debark` action that moves a person from an aircraft to a city. The action has the effect of making the person located in the city and no longer in the aircraft.

The constraint is about limiting how many times a person can be debarked in the same city. This is a trajectory constraint that needs to be expressed in terms of states, not actions.

Let me think about how to decompose this:

1. The constraint is about the cumulative effect of debark actions - specifically that no person should be debarked more than once in any given city.

2. Looking at the domain, there's a function `(n_debark ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)` that tracks the number of times a person has been debarked from an aircraft in a city.

3. Since we want to ensure a person is never debarked in the same city more than once, this means for any person and any city, the total number of debark operations across all aircraft should not exceed 1.

4. However, I need to be careful here - the constraint should be state-based and in natural language, not referring to PDDL functions directly.

Let me rephrase this in natural language terms that capture the meaning:

The constraint means that once a person has been debarked (gotten off an aircraft) in a particular city, they should never be debarked in that same city again, regardless of which aircraft they might be traveling on.

This can be expressed as: for each person and each city, the total count of times that person has been debarked in that city should never exceed 1.

Since I need to avoid PDDL language and make it state-based, I should express this in terms of what we can observe in the world state:

1. 

I'll clarify the constraint's core principle: a traveler can only exit an aircraft in a specific location one time. This means once someone has left a plane in a particular city, they cannot repeat that action in the same urban environment. The rule prevents multiple disembarkations in an identical city, ensuring each person's journey has a unique initial arrival point.

<constraints>
1. For each person and each city combination, the total number of times that person has gotten off an aircraft in that city should never exceed one.
</constraints>

<explanation>
The constraint directly translates to limiting the debark count for each person-city pair to at most one occurrence throughout the entire plan execution. This ensures no person can be debarked multiple times in the same city, regardless of which aircraft they travel on.
</explanation>
